page.title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3)

revision.comment: removed terrible sentence, minor copy edits
revision.text:
{{Infobox television season |season_name = Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (season 3) |bgcolour = #B60000 |italic_title = no |image = |caption = |country = United States |num_episodes = 47 |network = [[Television syndication|Syndication]] |first_aired = {{Start date|1989|9|25}} |last_aired = {{End date|1990|7|24}} |region_1 = |region_2 = |region_3 = |region_4 = |region_5 = |region_A = |region_B = |region_C = |region_free = |prev_season = [[Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 2)|Season 2]] |next_season = [[Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 4)|Season 4]] |episode_list = List of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) episodes }} The '''third season''' of ''[[Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series)|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles]]'' aired in syndication. For most of this season, the [[Technodrome]] is located at the [[Inner core|Earth's core]]. Transport modules with drills are used to travel between the Technodrome and the Earth's surface.{{cite web|url=http://www.adventuresinpoortaste.com/2012/12/27/teenage-mutant-ninja-turtles-1987-season-3-review-part-one/|title=Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987) Season 3 Review (Part One)|publisher=Adventures in Poor Taste|language=English|first=Mark|last=Pellegrini|date=27 December 2012|accessdate=10 December 2015}} ==Episodes== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" width="100%" |- style="color:white;" ! style="background:#B60000; "| No. in
series ! style="background:#B60000; "| No. in
season ! style="background:#B60000; "| Title ! style="background:#B60000; "| Directed by ! style="background:#B60000; "| Written by ! style="background:#B60000; "| Original air date ! style="background:#B60000; "| TV
broadcast {{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=19 |EpisodeNumber2=1 |Title=Beneath These Streets |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=[[Michael Reaves]] |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|10|18}} |ProdCode=S03E01 |ShortSummary= The Turtles learn the cost of slacking off when [[Splinter (TMNT)|Splinter]] is badly hurt during a confrontation with [[Shredder (TMNT)|Shredder]]. '''Villain:''' Shredder |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=20 |EpisodeNumber2=2 |Title=Turtles on Trial |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=[[Michael Reaves]] |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|10|19}} |ProdCode=S03E02 |ShortSummary= The intentions of the Turtles are put to the test when a controversial TV-figure portrays our heroes as menaces to society. The Turtles forego publicly clearing their name to defeat [[Krang]] and his new robotic weapon. '''Note:''' First appearance of Krang's "bubble walker" '''Villains:''' Shredder and Krang |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=21 |EpisodeNumber2=3 |Title=Attack of the 50-Foot Irma |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=[[Rowby Goren]] |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|10|20}} |ProdCode=S03E03 |ShortSummary= Irma accidentally becomes gigantic and her naturally clumsy nature makes her a danger to the city. The Turtles and [[April O'Neil]] hide her and search for her cure. '''Villain:''' Shredder Title Reference: ''[[Attack of the 50 Foot Woman]]''. |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=22 |EpisodeNumber2=4 |Title=The Maltese Hamster |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=[[David Wise (writer)|David Wise]] |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|10|23}} |ProdCode=S03E04 |ShortSummary= Gangsters are swiping all the antiques in town. And when they swipe most of our heroes, it's up to Donatello and April to find out why. Could Shredder be behind this? '''Villain:''' Shredder Title Reference: ''[[The Maltese Falcon (novel)|The Maltese Falcon]]'' '''Note:''' Krang is not in this episode. '''Note:''' In this episode, Burne Thompson is voiced by [[Townsend Coleman]] instead of [[Pat Fraley]]. |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=23 |EpisodeNumber2=5 |Title=Sky Turtles |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=[[Reed Shelly]] and [[Bruce Shelly]] |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|10|24}} |ProdCode=S03E05 |ShortSummary= The Turtles go flying when the Shredder invents a gravity-altering device. Soon it extends to the surface and affects all of New York City. '''Villain:''' Shredder |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=24 |EpisodeNumber2=6 |Title=The Old Switcheroo |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=Michael Reaves |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|10|25}} |ProdCode=S03E13 |ShortSummary= The bodies of Shredder and Splinter are switched when a device is accidentally activated during a battle between the Turtles and their enemies. As Shredder plans the Turtles' demise and Splinter plans on how to get back to his body, everyone else is clueless. '''Villain:''' Shredder |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=25 |EpisodeNumber2=7 |Title=Burne's Blues |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=''Story by'': Bill Wolf
''Teleplay by'': Gordon Bressack |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|10|26}} |ProdCode=S03E10 |ShortSummary= In the middle of a summer heat wave, someone is destroying all the air conditioners and taking all the city's freon. In the meantime, Vernon and Burne go looking for the Turtles, but find something else. '''Villain:''' Shredder '''Note:''' First appearance of Don Turtelli, who makes a brief cameo. |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=26 |EpisodeNumber2=8 |Title=The Fifth Turtle |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=Francis Moss |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|10|27}} |ProdCode=S03E07 |ShortSummary= A 13-year-old boy tries his best to help out the Turtles, but with some not so optimal results. In the end, he proves himself to be a great asset to the Turtle team. '''Villain:''' Shredder '''Note:''' First appearance of Zach and his brother Walt. |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=27 |EpisodeNumber2=9 |Title=Enter the Rat King |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=Buzz Dixon |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|10|30}} |ProdCode=S03E12 |ShortSummary= A mysterious, sewer-dwelling man has an unnatural ability to put rats under his control. Can Splinter resist, or will he destroy the Turtles at the bidding of the [[Rat King (Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles)|Rat King]]?. '''Villain:''' The Rat King mysterious-dwelling man '''Note:''' This is the very first episode not to feature Shredder. '''Note:''' First appearance of the Rat King. '''Note:''' In this episode, Burne Thompson is voiced by Townsend Coleman instead of Pat Fraley. |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=28 |EpisodeNumber2=10 |Title=Turtles at the Earth's Core |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=Michael Reaves |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|10|31}} |ProdCode=S03E17 |ShortSummary= After witnessing a living dinosaur wander in the city and disappear abruptly, the Turtles follow its tracks into a large hole, where they discover a shocking revelation: A cave where dinosaurs still roam. Meanwhile, Shredder and his mutant goons, [[Bebop and Rocksteady]], are also there, but to collect a crystal needed by Krang to recharge the power cells of the Technodrome. The Turtles discover that the crystal is the source for all lifeforms inside the cave, and must get it back before they are all destroyed. '''Villains:''' Shredder, Krang, Bebop and Rocksteady Title Reference: ''[[Tarzan at the Earth's Core]]'' |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=29 |EpisodeNumber2=11 |Title=April Fool |RTitle= {{Small|A.K.A.}} "April Foolish" |DirectedBy=Reg Lodge |WrittenBy=Michael Reaves and [[Brynne Stephens]] |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|11|1}} |ProdCode=S03E35 |ShortSummary= Emperor Aleister of Malicuria comes to the United States with a sample of Lydium 90, which gets noticed by Krang as a way to power up the Technodrome, which has constant brownouts. To celebrate relations between Malicuria and the US, the Emperor hosts a masquerade ball in New York, but his bored daughter, Princess Mallory sneaks out for a night on the town. April crashes the party dressed as a princess, and gets mistaken for Mallory, but the masquerade is also crashed by Shredder, Bebop and Rocksteady, who plans to kidnap Mallory in order to get the Lydium 90 shard. '''Villains:''' Shredder, Krang, Bebop and Rocksteady '''Note:''' This episode is inspired by [[Mark Twain]]'s [[the Prince and the Pauper]]. |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=30 |EpisodeNumber2=12 |Title=Attack of Big MACC |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=Francis Moss |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|11|2}} |ProdCode=S03E14 |ShortSummary= A robot warrior, known as the Mobile Armored Computerized Combatant (M.A.C.C.), arrives from 400 years in the future in 20th-Century New York. He befriends the Turtles, but Shredder and Krang are looking to bring him to their side, at any means necessary. '''Villains:''' Shredder and Krang '''Note:''' In this episode, [[Ace Duck]] is briefly seen on the Turtles' television screen, marking this as his only on-screen appearance in the series. |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=31 |EpisodeNumber2=13 |Title=The Ninja Sword of Nowhere |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=Michael Edens and Mark Edens |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|11|3}} |ProdCode=S03E08 |ShortSummary= Shredder gains possession of an ancient ninja sword that is crafted from an alien metal, allowing it to 'cut' through dimensions. '''Villain:''' Shredder '''Note:''' In this episode Raphael is voiced by [[Thom Pinto]] instead of [[Rob Paulsen]]. |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=32 |EpisodeNumber2=14 |Title=20,000 Leaks Under the City |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=Bob Schooley and Mark McCorkle |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|11|6}} |ProdCode=S03E09 |ShortSummary= Krang and Shredder's plan to flush out the Turtles from the sewers leaves the city flooded with water (and creatures!) from the ocean. Title Reference: ''[[20,000 Leagues Under the Sea]]'' '''Villains:''' Shredder, Krang, Bebop and Rocksteady '''Note:''' Final Appearance of Tiffany. '''Note:''' In this episode, both Donatello and Bebop are voiced by [[Greg Berg]] instead of [[Barry Gordon]]. |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=33 |EpisodeNumber2=15 |Title=Take Me to Your Leader |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=David Wise |ProdCode=S03E19 |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|11|7}} |ShortSummary= Worried that Shredder will soon win, Leonardo takes some time off, doubting his leadership. Meanwhile, Krang and Shredder drain solar energy from the Sun for the dual purpose of powering the Technodrome and capitulating Earth into another Ice Age. Without Leonardo, the three other Turtles try to thwart Shredder while taking turns as leader, but each realizes they need to overcome their own flaws, such as Raphael sticking to a decision, Michaelangelo becoming more serious and Donatello needing to analyze even the most obvious facts. '''Villains:''' Shredder and Krang |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=34 |EpisodeNumber2=16 |Title=Four Musketurtles |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=[[Doug Molitor]] |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|11|8}} |ProdCode=S03E16 |ShortSummary= A bump on the head leaves Leonardo thinking that he is in 17th century France, and that he and his comrades are Musketeers. '''Villain:''' Shredder, Bebop and Rocksteady Title Reference: ''[[The Three Musketeers]]'' '''Note:''' In this episode, both Donatello and Bebop are voiced by Greg Berg instead of Barry Gordon. '''Note:''' This episode was part of the TV Teddy video range where the titular teddy bear interacted with scenes and the presenter of the video. |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=35 |EpisodeNumber2=17 |Title=Turtles, Turtles, Everywhere |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=David Bennett Carren and J. Larry Carroll |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|11|9}} |ProdCode=S03E22 |ShortSummary= Shredder programs the city's new garbage collecting super-computer to collect the Turtles. But when Shredder doesn't specify 'Ninja' Turtles, the super-computer collects them all! Turtles of the city of every shape and size are not safe. '''Villain:''' Shredder |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=36 |EpisodeNumber2=18 |Title=Cowabunga Shredhead |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=[[Duane Capizzi]] and Steve Roberts |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|11|10}} |ProdCode=S03E06 |ShortSummary= Shredder thinks he's Michelangelo after a computer malfunction. Donatello races for an antidote before Shredder drains a naval nuclear submarine of all its power, and things get crazy when Rocksteady takes a dose of the potion and falls in love with April. '''Villain:''' Shredder and Krang '''Note:''' In this episode, both Krang and Burne Thompson are voiced by Townsend Coleman instead of Pat Fraley. |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=40 |EpisodeNumber2=22 |Title=Return of the Fly |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=Michael Reaves |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|11|16}} |ProdCode=S03E31 |ShortSummary= [[Baxter Stockman]] returns for revenge against the Turtles and Shredder, while our heroes attempt to stop Shredder's plan to siphon water from an underground reservoir. Maybe this new 'hero' can help the Turtles. '''Villains:''' Shredder and Krang '''Note:''' First appearance of Casey Jones. '''Note:''' First episode not to feature Master Splinter. |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=42 |EpisodeNumber2=24 |Title=Mutagen Monster |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=Michael Edens and Mark Edens |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|11|20}} |ProdCode=S03E27 |ShortSummary= A train accident produces gallons of mutagen that drench nearby cattle. The result is a super bull with a temper! Casey Jones helps the Turtles uncover who's behind a new wave of corporate crime. '''Villain:''' Shredder '''Note:''' Krang is not in this episode. |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=44 |EpisodeNumber2=26 |Title=Pizza by the Shred |DirectedBy=Reg Lodge |WrittenBy=Michael Edens and Mark Edens |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|11|22}} |ProdCode=S03E41 |ShortSummary= Michelangelo gets a job as a pizza delivery boy. But who's his new boss? '''Villain:''' Shredder |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=45 |EpisodeNumber2=27 |Title=Super Bebop & Mighty Rocksteady |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=David Carren and Larry Carroll |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|11|23}} |ProdCode=S03E11 |ShortSummary= Shredder and Krang produce hi-tech versions of Rocksteady and Bebop to keep the Turtles busy while they install a damaged mind-controlling Mesmerizer at the top of the broadcast tower at the Channel 6 building. Shredder's replaced, Leonardo's met his match. Shredder, Bebop and Rocksteady are sent to use it on the Turtles, and our heroes have a few close calls. After Master Splinter's favorite kimono is stolen, April's famous detective aunt helps the Turtles retrieve it. The two villains end up arguing, then finally fighting each other instead of the Turtles. '''Note:''' Shredder, Krang, Bebop and Rocksteady are not in this episode. '''Villains:''' Leatherhead and the Rat King |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=57 |EpisodeNumber2=39 |Title=The Gang's All Here |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=James A. Davis |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|12|11}} |ProdCode=S03E46 |ShortSummary= Bebop and Rocksteady put on an act to get the Turtles to eat cookies, but not any ordinary cookies, because these cookies could turn them into humans! Tempted to find out what being a human is like, Michelangelo eats one and becomes one. While the effects wears off from time to time, they still kick back in. Meanwhile, the Turtles search for Michelangelo with an antidote for the anti-mutagen before it destroys him, while Shredder's two mutant goons ask for help from their old gang to rob a ship. And during it all, April attempts to "join" the gang to get a story for Burne. '''Villains:''' Shredder, Bebop, Rocksteady, and Bebop and Rocksteady's gang Title Reference: ''[[Hail, Hail, the Gang's All Here]]'' |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=58 |EpisodeNumber2=40 |Title=The Missing Map |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=David Wise |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|12|12}} |ProdCode=S03E47 |ShortSummary= Zach's big brother, Walt, steals a rare pouch containing the only map to the Turtles' lair. '''Villains:''' Don Turtelli, the Great Boldini, and The Rat King '''Note:''' Shredder, Krang, Bebop and Rocksteady are not in this episode. '''Note:''' Final Appearance of Don Turtelli. '''Note:''' Master Splinter is not in this episode. |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=60 |EpisodeNumber2=42 |Title=Mister Ogg Goes to Town |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=David Wise |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|12|14}} |ProdCode=S03E38 |ShortSummary= An impish alien comedian from Dimension Z (who has mannerisms similar to Pee Wee Herman), escapes to Earth to cause big trouble for the TMNT. '''Villains:''' Shredder and Mr. Ogg Title Reference: ''[[Mr. Deeds Goes to Town]]'' |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=61 |EpisodeNumber2=43 |Title=Shredderville |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=Francis Moss |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|12|15}} |ProdCode=S03E28 |ShortSummary= The Turtles enter an alternate universe in which they dreamed that they never existed, where Shredder rules the city as Shredderville. '''Note:''' In this episode, Shredder is voiced by Dorian Harewood instead of James Avery. '''Note:''' Loosely based on the movie ''[[It's a Wonderful Life]]'' '''Villain:''' Shredder |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=62 |EpisodeNumber2=44 |Title=Bye, Bye, Fly |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=David Wise |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|12|18}} |ProdCode=S03E32 |ShortSummary= An interdimensional alien spacecraft leads Baxter Stockman to his latest vengeful plot to destroy the Turtles and Shredder. '''Note:''' First appearance of spaceship computer '''Villains:''' Shredder and Baxter Stockman '''Note:''' Final episode where Shredder is voiced by Dorian Harewood instead of James Avery. |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=63 |EpisodeNumber2=45 |Title=The Big Rip Off |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=Michael Reaves |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|12|19}} |ProdCode=S03E42 |ShortSummary= After several failed attempts to get the Technodrome re-energized, Shredder and Krang run one last-ditch distraction for the Turtles at Fort Charles while Bebop and Rocksteady steal energy fuel cells from the neighboring space research center. '''Villains:''' Shredder, Krang, Bebop and Rocksteady |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=64 |EpisodeNumber2=46 |Title=The Big Break In |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=David Wise |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|12|20}} |ProdCode=S03E43 |ShortSummary= The Technodrome is up and running again, and it is up to the Turtles to hinder Shredder and Krang from getting to the surface. '''Villains:''' Shredder and Krang |LineColor=B60000 }}{{Episode list/sublist|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) (season 3) |EpisodeNumber=65 |EpisodeNumber2=47 |Title=The Big Blow Out |DirectedBy=Bill Wolf |WrittenBy=David Wise |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1989|12|21}} |ProdCode=S03E44 |ShortSummary= After several setbacks, including firing a missile towards the turtles out at the [[South Dakota]] countryside, missing and instead blowing up [[Mount Rushmore]], Shredder and Krang steal all of New York's electricity and charge it into a giant transdimensional gateway, designed to send Earth into Dimension X. The Turtles must defeat their enemies once and for all before Earth is destroyed by Krang's Rock Soldier army. At the end, the turtles send the Technodrome to Dimension X and are celebrated as the heroes in town. '''Villains:''' Shredder and Krang '''Note:''' This is the last episode to air before the release of the first [[Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1990 film)|live action film adaption]]. |LineColor=B60000 }} |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0131613/episodes?season=3&ref_=tt_eps_sn_3 IMDB] *[http://www.tv.com/shows/teenage-mutant-ninja-turtles-1987/season-3/ TV Com] {{Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' (1987 TV series) (season 3)}} [[Category:Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series) seasons]] [[Category:1989 American television seasons]] [[Category:South Dakota in fiction]] [[Category:Florida in fiction]] [[Category:Meteoroids in fiction]] [[Category:Parallel universes in fiction]] [[Category:Floods in fiction]] [[Category:Sun in fiction]] [[Category:Polaris in fiction]] [[Category:Antares in fiction]] [[Category:Fiction about consciousness transfer]] [[Category:Fictional subterranea]] [[Category:Television series set in feudal Japan]]
